title: Why are premeds so afraid of organic chemistry? - Quora

response.answer_text: As someone who is seeking to pursue medicine in the future (if everything works out), here’s my own experience. This is obviously anecdotal but maybe some people will glean info from it. In high school, I absolutely loved chemistry. I thought understanding chemistry meant understanding why the world functions. So much can be derived from chemistry. And with my father having a PhD in organic chemistry, he helped instill a love of chemistry for me. I remember a lot of my friends saying the chemistry was hard in high school but I never could understand. I decided to use my AP Chem credit and skip gen chem and jump right into organic chemistry. Not only the “premed” organic chemistry, but the “honors” organic chemistry meant for those interested in majoring in organic chemistry and going for a masters or PhD afterwards in chemistry. Then during the summer, I told some of my friends that were sophmores and juniors in college that I wanted to go medical school. Almost all of them replied, “good luck in Ochem” or something of the sorts. I initially just ignored then but the repeated statements regarding Ochem started to get to me. I was thinking “da*n ochem must be truly hell for so many people to comment on it.” I saw some of my sophomore friends stop being premed because Ochem ruined them. With this, I kept worrying that I would join the many who got “ruined” by Ochem. I now wanted to undo my AP credit and just do gen chem over again and avoid ochem for as long as possible. Luckily, my dad said that would be foolish and just go for it. He would be able to help me if I needed it. I’m greatful I listened to him. Even still, I dreaded what awaited me. So day 1 of college, and I’m the only freshman in a class of sophomores majoring in chemistry. Its reviewing resonance structures. I’m like “this is soooo easy, what is the fuss? It’s just gen chem again.” But I also think “this is day 1 lets wait a month and see how I’m feeling.” So its the end of month 1, and we’ve just had our first exam. I set the curve. I scored 99% raw score but actually got 113% after the curve is applied. Now, you might be thinking, well that’s just cause this guy must be really good at ochem and has a father that major in organic chemistry. And guess what, you’re wrong. I never asked my dad for any help but what I did do was study my “a**” off. Everyday, I would spend at least an hour reviewing what had been covered and really understanding what was going on. No I don’t mean I memorized each reaction because guess what. That’s not learning. Monkeys can be trained to regurgitate information. No, I really sat down and “understood” what was occurring. Say we learned that a grignard plus a ketone makes a tertiary alcohol after acid workup. What many would do is just “memorize” this fact. Memorize. Rinse and repeat. Easy right? Well that’t not how I thought about. I had so many questions. “Well aldehydes are like ketones. Would they react similarly?” “Why is an acid workup necessary?” “Why did he say acid work up afterwards, what if I changed it and did an acid work up before?” “What if I changed the acid workup into a base workup?” “What is physically happening so that this reaction goes to completion? Why don’t they just not react?” So, instead of just “memorizing” this fact and moving on. I dug in. I started looking up resources on “grignard reactions” and found a treasure trove. Specifically, I really appreciated the “reaction mechanism” of it. This is a procedure of drawing arrows and electrons that helps to explain what is occurring. I saw that the grignard is electron donating and makes the carbon effectively at like it was a carboanion. Of course, this is unstable so, it then moves this negative charge to the ketone. It attacks the carbon so that the double bond can be broken and the electrons then move onto the oxygen. Next, acid is added so that the negative oxygen can now be an alcohol. The reaction is now finished. This helped answer that aldehydes could react similar since the reasonable mechanism could be draw for them as well. It also explained why an acid was necessary. I also realized from it why an acid had to be added afterwards. Remember when I said that the grignard makes the carbon negative? Well, what else is negative? Bases!!!! I realize that grignards are also bases. So, if I add an acid, an acid base rxn would occur rather than the attack. So out of this you might be wondering. Why is it necessary to even consider this? Who honestly cares? You spend so much more time doing this then just memorizing. Well, on test day, we have a question. Say we have a grignard and a carboxylic acid. What would the product be? We had never been taught a grignard plus a carboxylic acid so I panic a little. But then after calming down, I thought about the question. Grignards generally attack a carbon and push electrons onto the oxygen. This could reasonable happen. Carboxylic acids has a similar double bonded oxygen. But then I also remeebr, carboxylic acids are called that because they are ACIDS. So recalling what I had realized earlier about acid work ups, I realized an acid base reaction would occur. I was one of the few on the test to get it right. If I were to guess, it would be something like this. 1/4 the class didn’t know the answer cause we hadn’t been taught this case. 1/2 the class thought the answer would be similar to an aldehyde or ketone and just add the grignard reagent onto the carboxylic acid. However, by truly understanding the rxn, I realized the real answer. And, from there, I just kept doing what I had been doing for grignards. Looking deeper. Now I’m taking graduate classes in Ochem for “fun” my sophomore year and I am loving it. I’m getting a ever greater understanding of why reactions occur. SOOOO. What can we get out of this anedote? Don’t get pulled into the hype. Ochem isn’t as hard as people say it is. Do your own thing and ignore everyone else.Study smarter not harder. Memorization is necessary for basic recall but it alone won’t save you. Truly understanding concepts is how you do well in Ochem. Spend the time to really know why something is occurring not just accepting it for fact. This extends well beyond Ochem and this though pattern has been helping me ever since.Thanks for reading.

Orgo, very often, is graded on a curve. 20–30% of a class will get a grade below B. Some colleges won’t allow a pre-Med to continue with a grade below B. Even if allowed to continue, chances of obtaining a Med school admission will be jeopardized. The curve isn’t arbitrary. Exams are just very hard. For most students, the material itself isn’t particularly demanding. However, there is a lot of it and the student is expected to know all of it (my Orgo textbook was 1200 pages). In addition, they’ll be required to integrate multiple concepts to solve problems. The first exam might have an average of, say, 65%. This is intended as a wake up call. Forewarned, students bear down harder for the second exam only to see an average of 45%. If a student falls behind, it’s very, very hard to catch up. Some very bright students struggle with three-dimensional perception. Imagine a student who is used to all A’s in both sciences and humanities not only flunking an exam but getting a grade of zero. Others seemed to have little common sense - trying to light a Bunsen burner that was spewing water instead of gas; trying to pull a vacuum through a solid glass rod instead of a hollow tube, etc. Students who are successful at Orgo put in a lot of time. I don’t know anyone for whom Orgo was easy. If they liked it and were good at it, they still had to put in a lot of time. Three hours of study for each hour of class was the rule of thumb (not including labs, lab reports or preparation for quizzes and exams). For students who really wanted to do well, 5–7 hours was more typical. Pre meds have a reputation - deserved or not - of being grade grubbers. Many would appeal a grade of, say, 3 out of fifteen because someone else received a 4 or 5 for a very similar answer. One professor was getting appeals from two thirds of his students. He announced that he would still entertain appeals but would regrade the entire exam. Appeals fell over 90%. Orgo is said to be the closest comparison to Med school curriculum. Those who cannot do well in Orgo are unlikely to succeed in med school. Med schools know this and expect to see students who can master the subject. Rigorous pre med programs apply tough love. Those that use Orgo and other pre med courses to weed out the uncommitted have very high success rates(90+%) for Med school applicants (that is, those who survived the pre med gauntlet until Senior year). Not all programs do this. Annually, over 100,000 take the MCAT. Presumably, they all took the required courses, including Orgo. Only ~21,000 will earn admission. Of course, Orgo is just one course. Pre meds have to do well in their other courses at the same time!
